testproblem.name: parallel_coarsening_3dThis tests 3D coarsening in parallel. We start from a uniform mesh of 30x30x30 in a cube, i.e. dx~0.033. There's no interpolation error specified, so it should just coarsen to a uniform mesh according to the maximum edge length of 0.1. This is run on 3 cores. On master this fails because of it failing to move around the halos sufficiently so that we can coarsen everywhere. With he new halo locking strategy that only locks a single row of elements this passes.

variables.variable: from fluidity_tools import stat_parser stat=stat_parser('coarsen.stat') cell_volume_stats = stat['Fields']['CellVolume']
from fluidity_tools import stat_parser stat=stat_parser('coarsen.stat') mesh_stats = stat['CoordinateMesh']

pass_tests.test: assert cell_volume_stats['min']>5e-6We've asked for a max. edge length of 0.1. This means a min volume (for a regular tetrahedron) of 0.1**3/(6*sqrt(2)) ~ 0.00012. We allow an order smaller volume.

assert cell_volume_stats['max']<0.0012This is to check we've coarsened everywhere. We've asked for a max. edge length of 0.1. This means a max volume (for a regular tetrahedron) of 0.1**3/(6*sqrt(2)) 0.00012. We allow a volume that is 10 times bigger.
assert 7000<mesh_stats['elements']<9600If we had all regular tetrahedron of volume 0.00012, we'd get ~8333 triangles. This test limits the *average* cell volume.
